Instead of repenting they feel they have to attack the messenger, and the source of the message - Jesus Christ and the Bible.

 The Temple Scroll and Crucifixion
 
 The following relates to "The Temple Scroll" (11QT - one of the Dead Sea Scrolls found at Qumran). The significance of what was found in this first century scroll confirms that the Jews of Jesus' time recommended and endorsed crucifixion for those whom they believed violated their religious beliefs. This evidence strongly counters the arguments of those who suggest that crucifixion was purely a Roman practice and that Jewish authorities therefore could not have been instrumental in recommending the crucifixion for Jesus.
 
 .....the Temple Scroll is evidence that the Jews practiced crucifixion against their own people during the period of Jesus' lifetime. In particular, column 64 describes in some detail the Essene understanding of Deuteronomy 21:22-23 which says: 
 
 "When someone is convicted of a crime punishable by death and is executed, and you hang him on a tree, fall night upon the tree; you shall bury him that same day, for anyone hung on a tree is under God's curse. You must not defile the land that the Lord your God is giving you for possession."
 
 The Essene interpretation of this passage is found in the Damascus Document 64.6-12 
 
 Thus you shall eradicate all evil in your midst, and all the children of Israel shall hear it and fear. If there were to be a spy against his people who betrays his people to a foreign nation or causes evil against his people, you shall crucify him and he will die. On the evidence of two witnesses and on the evidence of three witnesses shall he be executed and they shall crucify him. If there were a man with a sin punishable by death and he escapes amongst the nations and curses his people, the children of Israel, he also you shall crucify and he shall die. Their corpses shall not spend the night on the tree; instead you shall bury them that day because they are cursed by God and man, those crucified; thus you shall not defile the land which I give you.
 
 Perhaps the question has arisen in the reader's mind at this point, "what does this have to do with Jesus?" Well, the New Testament bears witness to the fact that Jesus was executed primarily because the Jews were angry at him because of his Sabbath practices. This Qumran text bears witness to the fact that crucifixion was used against those who "defiled" the land; and Sabbath breaking was defilement! Such defilers are cursed by God! 
 
 While it is clear that the Romans in fact crucified Jesus, that the Jewish leadership participated is also undeniable. Of course the actual order was reserved for the Roman prefect. But Jesus was handed over for execution after the Jews had decided that he must be executed.

 A nutshell answer to your question: modern man is the only extant species of a once widespread family, the Hominidae, which split from the ape family some 5 or more million years ago. Numerous fossil hominids are known, but the fragmentary nature of the fossil evidence makes relationships hard to discern. Among the known hominids are several types which are strong contenders as human ancestors, or at least as close relatives of those ancestors. An important observation is the chronology of the fossils: we never find sapiens before erectus, or erectus before habilis, and so on.
 
 Given the very low probability of hominid remains being fossilised in the first place, and then of those fossils coming to light in recent times, the fossil evidence for humans having evolved from pre-human hominids is probably as good as we could reasonably expect. You, of course, will continue to advertise your lack of understanding by calling for the 'missing link' to be produced. This is a figment of creationists' imagination: there is no single, discrete step between modern man and non-man. What we do have are specimens from some 500 000 years ago which combine features of early sapiens and late erectus. These are not 'the missing link', as the term has no meaning; but they are good indicators of transition.
 
 From time to time you ask, amusingly, for something you call 'conclusive DNA evidence' of human ancestry. You do so disingenuously, since you are aware that DNA does not survive in very old fossils; but even with that safety net, you still decline to clarify what, if it existed, you would accept as 'conclusive DNA evidence'. Apparently 98% overlap between human and chimp DNA is not enough to convince you of common ancestry; so what would?

 Address the emotions, and not the consciences, of your hearers.
 
 Be careful not to testify from your own experiences about the power of the Gospel and the Holy Spirit, lest you should produce the conviction upon your hearers hearts and minds that you have experienced something they need.
 
 Denounce sin in general, but make no reference to specific sins that the politically correct mind might deem offensive. 
 
 Do not give the impression that God commands your listeners here and now to obey the truth. Do not let them think that you expect them to turn anytime soon from their worldly ways and give their lives to Christ. 
 
 Admit, either obviously or casually, that all men have sufficient moral goodness in them to get to heaven - lest sinners should understand that they need a radical change of heart from sin to holiness. Don't let them know that they need to repent and receive the perfect righteousness of Christ - achieved by grace through faith in him (Romans 3; Ephesians 2:8-9) - and be born again, in order to obtain salvation. Always let them think they're good enough on their own to please God and get into heaven. 
 
 Do not speak of the spirituality of God's holy law (by which comes the knowledge of sin), lest the sinner should recognize his lost condition.
 
 Make no appeals to the fears of sinners; but leave the impression that they have no reason to fear going to hell if they reject Christ.
 
 Always preach Christ as just an amiable and good-natured religious philosopher (but not the divine God and the only way to the Father), and ignore telling them about those scathing rebukes of sinners and hypocrites that he pronounced, which so often made his hearers tremble. Tell them the first part of the story of how he did not condemn the adulteress, but make sure you don't tell them the other part about, "Now go, and sin no more."
 
 Say so little about hell that people will think it doesn't really exist. Push the politically correct mindset that God would never send anyone to hell. Ignore all the teachings and parables about hell that Christ and others taught.
 
 Make no disagreeable references to the teachings of self- denial, cross-bearing, and crucifixion to the world, lest you should convict and convert people.
 
 Do not rebuke any worldly tendencies you find in society or in the church, lest you should hurt someone's feelings.
 
 Don't explain to them that sanctification by the Holy Spirit is a life-long process. Let them think that once someone has become a Christian they're automatically perfect. That way they can continue their rant that all Christians are hypocrites and say they don't want any part of them or their God. 
 
 Encourage current attitudes in pro gay and pro shack-up churches, so that they think they won't need to turn from their sins and false teachings. And even if, in your own mind, you admit that these things are sins, don't ever ask them yourself (personally) to repent or turn from their sinful ways. 
 
 Never take a stand against anything that's politically correct lest you become unpopular. 
 
 Even though the Bible says "Love does not rejoice in iniquity," and "Love does a neighbor no harm" (like enticing others into unbiblical sin), don't dare mention it. Instead, whenever the carnal minded tell you they love their (illicit sexual) partner, tell them that since it's love then it must be okay with God. 
 
 Never ask them how many souls they've personally led to Christ or who and for how long they've preached the Gospel to others. Tell them that's just something zealots do. 
 
 Tell them it's okay to change Good Friday and Christmas to "Spring Break" and the "Winter Holidays" so no one will get their politically correct feelings tweaked and be remotely reminded of Jesus Christ. Tell them two hundred years of Godly American traditions such as these were just narrow-minded nonsense to begin with. And make darn sure you don't do anything about this yourself. Just roll over and let some other mother's son take the heat and fight the fight. 
 
 Tell them it's always okay to use the term "Christian fundamentalist" in a negative way. Don't let them know that liberal fundamentalism, with all its anti-biblical worldliness, is in any way offensive to God or anyone else. And for sure don't remind them that Jesus Christ had his own Biblically-based, fundamental truths that he preached. 
 
 Tell them casual gossip and other personal attacks against fundamentalists is okay, since the fundamentalists are obviously screwed up anyway. Never ask them to document their hateful attacks with hard facts or, God forbid, rebuke the gossip. 
 
 Tell them voting for the politically correct candidate who, when elected, puts card-carrying ACLU, pro-partial-birth abortion justices on the bench is really good. 
 
 And finally, don't let them know that without conviction for their sins, there is no need for a Savior.

Wrong EZ, I am saying that your "truth" is simply not Christian. You can't find anything that Jesus said that supports it. What do you do about that?
 
 
If they object to something the Apostle Paul or someone else in the Bible wrote and say "I don't believe everything that's written in the Bible," don't ask them to document why it's not Biblical or what early manuscripts they've researched in making that determination. Just humor their "feel good" politically correct denials and tell them they're doing great in making those kinds of observations.
I don't object to anything anybody says in the Bible. I am a Christian and I think everything that is written in the Bible has to be viewed through the words, teachings and revelations of Jesus. That is a Christian view. The view of youR cut and paste is a Biblican view. That is fine, just don't say it is Christian because that is dishonest.
